unnormalised: Hey Delhi! Tired of seeing overflowing dhalaos? Well, there's some good news on the waste management front. IIT-Delhi just announced a breakthrough in converting agricultural waste, like paddy straw (remember those smog issues after Diwali?), into bio-degradable packaging material. Think less plastic, more sustainable chai-wallah cups!
normalised: Hey Delhi! Tired of seeing overflowing dhalaos? Well, there's some good news on the waste management front. I I T-Delhi just announced a breakthrough in converting agricultural waste, like paddy straw (remember those smog issues after Diwali?), into bio-degradable packaging material. Think less plastic, more sustainable chai-wallah cups!

unnormalised: The project, spearheaded by Dr. Sharma's team, promises to reduce stubble burning by a whopping 60% within 2 years if adopted widely. Plus, imagine the possibilities for packaging local mithai and snacks!
normalised: The project, spearheaded by Doctor Sharma's team, promises to reduce stubble burning by a whopping sixty percent within two years if adopted widely. Plus, imagine the possibilities for packaging local mithai and snacks!

unnormalised: This isn't just about clean streets; it's about circular economy, yaar. Remember "Lagaan"? Even they understood the value of resourcefulness! The Municipal Corporation of Delhi (MCD) is reportedly in talks with the institute to pilot the project in a few wards. Let’s hope this goes beyond talk and becomes a reality. Maybe soon we'll have cleaner Bharat Mata Ki Jai, with fewer landfills and happier cows munching on actual grass, not plastic. Fingers crossed!
normalised: This isn't just about clean streets; it's about circular economy, yaar. Remember "Lagaan"? Even they understood the value of resourcefulness! The Municipal Corporation of Delhi (M C D) is reportedly in talks with the institute to pilot the project in a few wards. Let’s hope this goes beyond talk and becomes a reality. Maybe soon we'll have cleaner Bharat Mata Ki Jai, with fewer landfills and happier cows munching on actual grass, not plastic. Fingers crossed!
